head.title: Ode VII. To Irvine Water.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 164-167.

lg.l: First, Irvine,22 The river Irvine flows through southwest Scotland, runs near Kilmarnock and down to the coastal town of the same name. Turnbull devoted two other poems to Irvine in Poetical Essays (1788): “Elegy IV" and “Irvine Water.” on thy banks I strung
The lyre, and love’s soft passion sung;
Then charming Maria33 Variant of Mary. was my theme,
Each rock repeated Maria’s name,
Though yet unskill’d to touch the lyre,
Her beauties could my verse inspire,
My songs the lagging hours beguil’d,
The fair one heard, and Phœbus44 The sun. smil’d.

A rapt Enthusiast55 Cf. “sweet enthusiast” in Turnbull’s “Elegy I” (1788), line 9, from John Dryden: At last divine Cecilia came, / … / The sweet enthusiast, from her sacred store, / Enlarged the former narrow bounds”: Alexander’s Feast, or the Power of Music (1697), lines 167, 173. now I seem,
Still wand’ring by thy winding stream,
Where, by a mould’ring rock, reclin’d,
I sooth my melancholy mind,
And sigh, in consort with the gale,
Or tell some love disastrous tale;
And, whilst the pensive numbers flow,
Discover charms that sweeten wo.
Amid the woodland’s awful gloom,

Appears a venerable dome66 [GT's note: Loudon church.] Located west of Loudoun Castle, Ayrshire, Loudoun Kirk was established c. 1451 and remained the parish church until the seventeenth century after which time it fell into a state of disrepair.
Whose consecrated walls contain
The bones of many an antient Thane,77 n. a minor noble who acted as an official of the Crown. Cf. Shakespeare, Macbeth (1623).
That, mould’ring in the narrow cell,
With ghosts of gloomy warriors dwell:
At midnight there the lyre was strung,
The hollow vault responsive rung.
Begin, sweet lyre, more cheering strains,
The most delightful task remains,
The Muse prepares, in smoother verse,
Thy beauties, Irvine, to rehearse.
All hail, ye shady green abodes,
Retreats of Pan,88 Greek god of flocks and shepherds and inventor of the musical pipe of seven reeds. and silvan Gods;
For thee, Arcadia99 Mountainous district in Greece often used to symbolize an ideal, rustic setting. they forsake,
And more delight in Scotia take.
With liberty, from Eastern climes,
From insult fled, and barb’rous crimes;
The Muses left the Grecian shore,
And hither brought their sacred lore;
Then Ceres1010 Roman Goddess of agriculture. taught the useful toil,
To guide the plough, and break the soil,
And, o’er the wide extended plain,
To rear the yellow waving grain.
Pomona1111 Wood nymph and Roman goddess of fruitful abundance. joins the sacred band,
And smiling Flora paints the land,
While art her utmost skill applies,
To make the stately fabric rise;
Then, charm’d with wonder, all appear’d,
And liberty her standard rear’d,
Till peace her olive branch display’d,
And grew enamour’d of the shade.
The shepherds, happy at the change,
Along thy flow’ry margin range;
While rural love and joy combine,
To render ev’ry bliss divine:
Each tunes, to rustic strains, the reed,
Their flocks and herds promiscuous feed,
Where, nodding to the passing gale,
Rich golden harvests clothe the dale.
Flow, gentle River, smooth along,
And murmur to the woodland song;
May, on thy banks, the Muses sing,
And hollow rocks responsive ring;
May plenty’s smiling face be seen,
Rejoicing on thy margin green;
May Commerce spread the swelling sail,
And arts and industry prevail.
